Dear Ms. Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 2/1/24 Staff 1 hit Youth T. Youth T had no injuries.
Investigation Video
Video shows Staff 1, Staff 2 and Staff 3 in the general living area
with Youth T. Staff 1 is hovered over a table documenting when
Youth T aggressively approaches her from the left with her left
arm extended. Staff 1 looks up, catches Youth T’s left arm, and
turns youth away from her. From behind Youth T Staff 1 hits her
in the back of her head three times and Staff 2 watches. Youth T
pivots and backs away from Staff 1. Staff 2 physically moves Staff
1 out of the room while Staff 3 remains seated.
Interviews:
I interviewed Complainant, also Supervisor via phone on 2/7/24.
She has worked at Vista Maria for six months. Complainant said
she did not witness Staff 1 hit Youth T. However, after the
incident Staff 1 told Supervisor she hit Youth T, handed in her
badge and keys, and walked out of the building. Staff 1 returned
to the building approximately 20 minutes later and continued
working. Supervisor did not know how Staff 1 got her badge and
keys back. Complainant stated, “Social Service Supervisor and I
talked to Staff 1 about the incident. Staff 1 told us Youth T threw
milk and juice on her. I asked Social Service Supervisor for the
video to be watched. On 2/6/24 video confirmed Staff 1 hit the
youth so Social Service Supervisor asked me to call it in. Staff 1
was placed on administrative leave on 2/6/24.”
I notified Youth T’s MDHHS worker of the investigation, and she
expressed no additional concerns.
2

I interviewed Youth T jointly with Government Worker 1 on 2/8/24.
She has been at the facility for one month. Youth T admitted she
was trying to “get at” Youth B when staff called to clear the area.
“Staff 2 was working. Everyone went into their rooms, and I
stayed out. I was yelling and pacing. Staff 2 was being fake.
Staff 1 asked “‘Why you keep fucking with this man?’ I answered,
‘Why the fuck you always in our business?’ I asked if she wanted
beef (meaning a problem). She said ‘No.’ I opened a milk from
the table and walked up to her threatening to dump it on her. Staff
1 said, ‘Ain’t nobody gonna play with you.’ She stood up and
knocked the milk on me. I dumped the rest on her. I said I’d write
a grievance on her. Staff 1 grabbed the grievance form and said,
‘Make sure you spell my name right.’ I grabbed yogurt, broke it
open and poured it on her. She started punching me on the back
of my head two or three times. Staff 2 got between us to break
her off of me. He moved her back and had her walk out. I
dumped fruit on her and said, ‘Guess who just lost her job?’ Staff
1 threw her Vista jacket in the trash...I was cool with her before
this.”
Youth T denied sustaining any marks or bruises as a result of
Staff 1 hitting her in the back of her head. However, she said she
was sent to the hospital thirty minutes later for a psychiatric
evaluation and has had no contact with Staff 1 since this incident.
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1 and Rights
Officer present on 2/8/24. Government Worker 1 read the
allegation aloud. Staff 1 described the incident stating a ‘clear the
area’ was called. “Youth T walked up to me with chocolate milk
and asked, ‘You want beef, bitch?’ Staff 2 was trying to verbally
deescalate. I grabbed the milk out of Youth T’s hand, and it went
everywhere. I grabbed her right hand and Staff 2 went to grab the
other hand to get the milk. Staff 2 got the milk. Youth T was still
holding onto us. She let go and I walked away. Youth T followed
me and threw grape juice and yogurt on me from behind. It got on
my shoes, jacket, and pants. I never hit her. She squared up. I
grabbed an arm to restrain her for throwing juice. Staff 2 came
and I let go. He escorted me to the door.”
Staff 1 denied hitting Youth T anywhere on her body. Before
leaving the building, she said she turned in her badge and keys,
and explained to Supervisor and Social Service Supervisor, “I
don’t think I can do this. I need to leave…That was the sixth or
seventh time I was assaulted by a youth.” Staff 1 said she went
out to her car and sat there for 30 minutes, and Team Leader
followed her and gave her back her badge and keys. They talked
3

and Staff 1 returned to Social Service Supervisor’s office. “She
(Social Service Supervisor) asked if I was okay. The police came
and asked if I wanted to press charges against Youth T for
throwing milk, juice and fruit on me.” Staff 1 denied telling
Supervisor she hit Youth T.
Due to the incident, Staff 1’s employment was terminated on
2/8/24 after she was interviewed by investigators.
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1 and Rights
Officer present via Teams on 2/15/24. He has worked at the
facility for nine months. Staff 2 recalled Youth T had been verbally
aggressive and pacing all day. “She (Youth T) got mad looking for
a reason to get after somebody. She opened milk and tried to
pour it on Staff 1. Staff 1 knocked the milk out of her hand. Youth
T grabbed yogurt. I seen Youth T and Staff 1 grabbed each other.
Youth T threw a fruit cup and I got Staff 1 off the unit.” Although
video footage shows Staff 2 witnessed Staff 1 respond
aggressively and hit Youth T in the back of her head, Staff 2
denied this upon interview.
I interviewed Staff 3 jointly with Government Worker 1 and Rights
Officer present via Teams on 2/15/24. She has worked at Vista
Maria for one year and is normally assigned to another building.
Staff 3 said she was unfamiliar with both Staff 1 and Youth T when
she started her shift on 1/30/24.
When she walked onto the unit Staff 3 said Youth T was pacing
the floor and the other youths were already cleared from the area.
“Youth T grabbed milk and attempted to pour it on Staff 1. Staff 1
jumped up and pushed Youth T’s shoulder back. Youth T tried to
pour juice on Staff 1. Staff 2 told Staff 1 to leave. Youth T tried to
pour juice on Staff 1 again. Staff 2 stepped in and got the juice. It
didn’t get on Staff 1, but she got really upset yelling.” I asked if
Staff 3 saw Staff 1 hit Youth T and she nodded affirmatively,
stating “That’s when Staff 2 told her to go. Youth T was saying
‘You just let her hit me?’”
Staff 3 did not intervene in the situation because she said she was
“from the outside” and did not know the youth. Asked if she wrote
an incident report, she responded, “They didn’t ask me to
complete one.” Video footage also shows Staff 3 witnessed Staff
1 hitting Youth T in the back of her head.
Documents reviewed:
4

An incident report by Staff 1 shows the incident occurred on
1/30/24 and not on 2/1/24 as the allegation suggested. Staff 1
described a two-hour time period in which Youth T displayed
multiple and consecutive provocative and aggressive behaviors
toward her and her peers. The report ended with Youth T
threatening to pour milk on Staff 1, Staff 1 and Staff 2 intervening,
Youth T pouring yogurt and grape juice on Staff 1, Staff 2
escorting Staff 1 to the exit door and the police transporting Youth
T to Garden City Hospital for a psychiatric evaluation.
I reviewed Staff 1’s employee record. There were attendance-
based write-ups, but nothing relative to displays of inappropriate
behavior with youth.
Government Worker 1 deemed Staff 1 unsuitable to work with
children.
Analysis Based on the video and youth and staff interviews, Staff 1 hit
Youth T three times in the back of her head in response to the
youth throwing milk and juice on her.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
Title required.
Rule Code & Rule 400.4131
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
Description assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238,
MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Two staff witnessed Staff 1 hitting Youth T and Complainant/
Supervisor was made aware that it happened. None of the three
staff reported this immediately to the appropriate government
agency.
Investigation Based on his presence and position in the video on 1/30/24, Staff
2 saw Staff 1 hit Youth T and did not report it immediately to the
appropriate government agency. Upon interview, Staff 3 admitted
seeing Staff 1 hit Youth T and did not report it. After the incident,
Complainant/Supervisor admitted Staff 1 told her she hit Youth T,
5

and she also did not report it to the appropriate government
agency until 2/6/2024.
Video shows Staff 2 and Staff 3 witnessed Staff 1 hitting Youth T
on 1/30/24.
A search of intakes for this program indicate Staff 2 and Staff 3 did
not report Staff 1 hitting Youth T to the appropriate government
agency.
Complainant/Supervisor is a mandated reporter but per the intake
in MiSACWIS she did not report the incident until 2/6/2024.
Analysis Three staff who are mandated reporters witnessed or were aware
of the abuse of a child by a person responsible for her care and
did not immediately report it to the appropriate government
agency as indicated in the Child Protection Law.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
